docs.snippet: WALKING WITH the spring of a young woman, her dark hair pulled back in a bun  as if to highlight her bright green eyes and ready smile, Maya Plisetskaya was carrying a little red canvas bag with everything she needed -- a tape recorder,  black tights...
docs.lead_paragraph: WALKING WITH the spring of a young woman, her dark hair pulled back in a bun as if to highlight her bright green eyes and ready smile, Maya Plisetskaya was carrying a little red canvas bag with everything she needed -- a tape recorder, black tights and ballet shoes -- for her daily workout at the Bavarian State Ballet School here in her adopted home city. For her legions of fans around the world, Ms. Plisetskaya has long been enshrined as one of this century's greatest ballerinas. For the petite and famously combative Russian star, though, what really counts is that at the age of 70 she is still dancing. And when she is not on the road, she spends 45 minutes in the morning exercising and rehearsing alongside dancers young enough to be her grandchildren.

headline.main: A Russian Legend Carries On Without Russia

docs.snippet: The United States signaled today that it was withdrawing from the negotiations to liberalize world trade in maritime services, diplomats said, dealing another blow to the fledgling World Trade Organization.         The diplomats said an American...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States signaled today that it was withdrawing from the negotiations to liberalize world trade in maritime services, diplomats said, dealing another blow to the fledgling World Trade Organization. The diplomats said an American official had said at a meeting of the World Trade Organization that it did not consider the market-access offers on the table sufficient for it to join fully in the negotiations, after two years of talks.

headline.main: U.S. Hints About a Withdrawal From Talks on Maritime Trade

docs.snippet: Plans to begin blasting rock formations in the Paraguay-Parana rivers this June, a preliminary step in a proposed 2,000-mile water highway linking five South American countries, have prompted sharp criticism from environmentalists.  They say this...
docs.lead_paragraph: Plans to begin blasting rock formations in the Paraguay-Parana rivers this June, a preliminary step in a proposed 2,000-mile water highway linking five South American countries, have prompted sharp criticism from environmentalists. They say this violates pledges that the waterway's construction would depend on the outcome of environmental studies. The five-country consortium behind the Hydrovia project, a waterway that would run from Caceres, Brazil, to Punta del Este, Uruguay, says it is awaiting results of a comprehensive environmental impact study, which is expected to be completed this year, before beginning work. The project calls for straightening and dredging the rivers, controlling the flow of tributaries with dikes and removing rock formations to allow year-round shipping.

headline.main: Ecologists Criticize First Steps in Latin River Plan

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WATERWAYS AND OTHER BODIES OF WATER

docs.snippet: Jerry R. Junkins, who rose from the factory floor to become chairman of Texas Instruments Inc., where he helped revive the American computer chip industry during the last decade, died yesterday. He was 58 and lived in Dallas.         Mr. Junkins...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jerry R. Junkins, who rose from the factory floor to become chairman of Texas Instruments Inc., where he helped revive the American computer chip industry during the last decade, died yesterday. He was 58 and lived in Dallas. Mr. Junkins suffered a heart attack while on a business trip to Stuttgart, Germany, where he was visiting customers, said Stan Victor, a spokesman for Texas Instruments. Mr. Junkins had no history of heart disease, Mr. Victor said.

headline.main: Jerry R. Junkins, 58, Dies; Headed Texas Instruments

docs.snippet: IN its heyday the Belmont Stakes had no trouble living up to its reputation as the crown jewel of horse racing. As the final -- hence, at times most suspenseful -- Triple Crown race, a mention of its name conjured up majestic images, Secretariat...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN its heyday the Belmont Stakes had no trouble living up to its reputation as the crown jewel of horse racing. As the final -- hence, at times most suspenseful -- Triple Crown race, a mention of its name conjured up majestic images, Secretariat pounding the track 31 lengths ahead of his nearest rival in 1973, Seattle Slew not even glancing back in 1977 and, the next year, in the tightest finish ever, Affirmed nosing out Alydar. But as the track gears up for the 128th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, the people whose lives are inexorably linked with the fortunes and grandeur of horse racing, many of whom grew up around race tracks, are watching the end of their world as they know it.

headline.main: At Belmont, Once Again The Future Is Uncertain

docs.snippet: Ian W. Delaney, chairman of the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian metals company with mining interests in Cuba, has just been warned by the State Department that he, his wife and his children may never be allowed to  enter the United...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ian W. Delaney, chairman of the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian metals company with mining interests in Cuba, has just been warned by the State Department that he, his wife and his children may never be allowed to enter the United States again. At the same time, Congress is rattling sabers in Europe's direction, vowing -- with President Clinton's support -- that Total S.A., the big French oil concern, and other European companies that supply Iran's oil industry may not be able to get American bank loans or export their goods to the United States.

headline.main: Is the U.S. Souring on Free Trade?

docs.snippet: In a move that expands free trade in South America, Chile agreed today to join the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur, which includes the continent's largest trading partners, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.         The inclusion...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that expands free trade in South America, Chile agreed today to join the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur, which includes the continent's largest trading partners, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. The inclusion of Chile, the most economically developed country in the region, gives the Mercosur bloc access to a robust economy of 14 million people and to Chile's Pacific Ocean ports -- vital gateways to commerce with Asia.

headline.main: Chile Will Enter a Big South American Free-Trade Bloc

docs.snippet: Allegations of bribery involving I.B.M. and Argentina's largest bank have escalated into a crisis that threatens to damage I.B.M.'s business and reputation here.         The highly publicized case -- in which I.B.M. has been accused of paying bribes...
docs.lead_paragraph: Allegations of bribery involving I.B.M. and Argentina's largest bank have escalated into a crisis that threatens to damage I.B.M.'s business and reputation here. The highly publicized case -- in which I.B.M. has been accused of paying bribes to obtain a $250 million computer contract from the bank, the state-owned Banco de la Nacion -- has taken some startling twists in recent weeks. Banco de la Nacion canceled a $250 million contract with the company, and prosecutors opened investigations into other International Business Machines contracts with the Government.

headline.main: Argentine Cloud Over I.B.M. Grows Darker
